awd_titl_txt: NeTS: Large: Collaborative Research: GigaNets: A Path to Experimental Research in Millimeter Wave Networking
awd_abstract_narration:
Wireless communication technologies such as cellular and WiFi are indispensable for modern society. However, existing wireless networks are under severe stress due to the explosive demand caused by smart mobile devices capable of creating and consuming large amounts of multimedia content (especially images and video).  Meeting these demands is estimated to require 1000-fold increases in wireless network capacity, which cannot be obtained by incremental advances using existing spectrum. A promising approach for delivering the required revolutionary advances in wireless by employ the so-called 'millimeter (mm) wave' band, which has huge amounts of available spectrum (e.g., 7 GHz in the unlicensed 60 GHz band alone).  The wavelength in these bands is an order of magnitude smaller than that in today's wireless networks, drastically changing the physical and propagation characteristics: for example, mm waves are easily blocked by obstacles such as human bodies, but steerable antenna arrays with a very large number of elements  (up to 1000) can fit in compact form factors, enabling us to potentially steer around obstacles using bounces from reflectors.  As a consequence, realizing the potential for mm wave communication requires a comprehensive reexamination of existing wireless design principles, using an interdisciplinary approach that goes all the way from antenna design to network protocols.  The goal of this project is to take such an approach for establishing fundamental principles for design of next generation mm wave communication networks, with a research agenda combining cross-layer modeling, design, and performance evaluation, firmly grounded in experiment.  A key technical issue is to how to efficiently adapt electronically steerable arrays with a large number of elements, and to integrate them into network protocols.

The research is driven by the following cutting edge system concepts: (a) Cellular 1000X, aimed at relieving the cellular capacity bottleneck via 60 GHz cellular links delivering Gbps data rates to the mobile, together with a seamless extension to indoor networks; (b)  'Wireless fiber' backhaul at 140 GHz for enabling Cellular 1000X, based on easy to deploy outdoor wireless mesh networks with link speeds approaching 40-100 Gbps; (c) 40 Gbps indoor 60 GHz links, aimed at going beyond nascent industry efforts such as NG60 that aim to upgrade link speeds in the recently developed IEEE 802.11ad wireless local area network standard. The goal of this project is to design a system that will achieve the stated objectives, and prototype an advanced proof-of-concept that will help pave the way for eventual technology transfer leveraging the close ties of the project team to industry. A 60 GHz experimental platform developed to support the research will be made available to the research community, to stimulate a broader academic effort in this area.  

Due to the small carrier wavelengths, beamforming at both ends is critical to make the link budget work, but it is essential to make the beams electronically steerable to steer around obstacles (which ``look bigger at smaller wavelengths''), and to allow automatic network configuration. Cross-layer frameworks for resilient pencil beam networking for both Cellular 1000X and indoor WLANs will be developed and demonstrated.  These will incorporate compressive array adaptation techniques, a core innovation to be demonstrated in this project.  Compressive adaptation enables 3D beamforming for robust link budgets, steering around blockage, and spatial reuse, and enables scaling of both the number of antenna elements and the nodes in the network, unlike existing scan-based IEEE 802.11ad medium access control (MAC) techniques. System concepts to be designed and tested include (a) `Picocloud' network architectures that employ tight coordination between base stations and APs (for outdoor and indoor environments, respectively) to provide seamless connectivity in the face of blockage; (b) Integration of beamforming with spatial multiplexing in LoS or near-LoS environments, demonstrating the scaling of available degrees of freedom with carrier frequency through prototypes at 60 GHz and 140 GHz.

A reconfigurable phased array at 60 GHz will be developed and integrated with the NSF/CRI-funded WiMi software defined radio platform, in order to enable the preceding system-level explorations (while beamsteering ICs developed by industry have been incorporated into products, external control of the beamsteering coefficients is not available).  In addition, a hardware testbed for LoS spatial multiplexing at 140 GHz will be developed to demonstrate the potential for 'wireless fiber' backhaul links beyond 100 GHz.

GigaNets: A Path to Experimental Research in Millimeter Wave Networking

Wireless cellular and WiFi communication technologies are indispensable for modern society, but their capabilities are increasingly stressed by smart mobile devices capable of creating and consuming large amounts of multimedia content. Meeting this demand is estimated to require 1000-fold increases in wireless network capacity, which cannot be obtained by incremental advances using existing spectrum. A promising approach for delivering the required revolutionary advances in wireless by employing the millimeter wave (mmWave) band, which has huge amounts of available spectrum (e.g., 7 GHz in the unlicensed 60 GHz band alone). The wavelength in these bands is an order of magnitude smaller than that in today's wireless networks, making it possible to fit a very large number of antenna elements into a compact form factor (e.g., 10-100 antennas in a mobile device, and 100-1000 antennas at a base station).  Multiple antenna, or MIMO (multiple input multiple output), techniques are therefore a core feature:  the formation of pencil beams towards mobile users, which, together with the vastly larger available spectrum, can provide the required orders of magnitude gains in network capacity. Recent advances in radio frequency integrated circuits (RFICs) using low-cost silicon processes imply that mass market mmWave technology is on the horizon. However, the tiny wavelength also drastically changes the physical and propagation characteristics relative to today’s wireless systems: for example, mm waves are easily blocked by obstacles such as human bodies, but steerable antenna arrays with a very large number of elements (up to 1000) can fit in compact form factors, enabling us to potentially steer around obstacles using bounces from reflectors. As a consequence, realizing the potential for mmWave communication requires a comprehensive reexamination of existing wireless design principles, using an interdisciplinary approach that goes all the way from antenna design to network protocols. The GigaNets project (https://wcsl.ece.ucsb.edu/giganets) takes this approach for establishing fundamental principles for design of next generation mmWave communication networks, with a research agenda combining cross-layer modeling, design, and performance evaluation, firmly grounded in experiment.

The cellular industry has recognized the potential of mmWave communication, pushing forward with 5G technology including licensed millimeter wave bands at relatively low frequencies (28 GHz).  The GigaNets project looks well beyond emerging 5G standards, with fundamental progress in algorithms and protocols verified using experiments in the unlicensed 60 GHz band, and experimental demonstration of the feasibility of low-cost transceivers at 140 GHz. In addition to the initial focus on next-generation communications, the project scope was broadened to include exploration of novel mmWave sensing techniques. The project is led by the University of California, Santa Barbara (UCSB), and the team includes faculty from Stanford University, University of California-San Diego (UCSD), and University of Chicago.  Industry partners include Facebook, Samsung, Qualcomm and Global Foundries.

Research outcomes related to architectures, protocols and algorithms for future mmWave networks include: tracking mobile users with a fine-grained resolution that enables formation of pencil beams and steering around obstacles; modeling future picocellular systems in dense urban environments, demonstrating the potential for 1000 to 10000-fold gains in capacity; mmWave wireless backhaul designs that support flexible base station deployment without digging trenches to run optical fiber; sensing the mmWave radio environment to enable robust communication in the presence of blockage; exploring mmWave architectures for high-mobility vehicular applications. Hardware demonstrations of working communication links with low-cost RFICs and packaging at 130 and 140 GHz developed in this project show that spectrum above 100 GHz has the potential for mass market applications. Up to 8 Gbps data rates for a single data stream, and up to 32 Gbps for a line of sight (LoS) MIMO link, were demonstrated. In addition, the project developed efficient 60 GHz power amplifiers, and novel waveguide technology for transporting mmWaves at 130 GHz at rates of up to 36 Gbps per lane. Finally, outcomes related to mmWave sensing include: fundamental limits for short-range sensing; experimental demonstration of imaging using existing mmWave radios; exploration of applications to robot navigation.

The project has supported 10 graduate students who have graduated with their PhDs, and are working with large technology firms and start-up companies. These students represent a mix of backgrounds, including the electromagnetics of antennas and packages, integrated circuit design, signal processing, computer science, and networking, and hence benefit significantly, in terms of interdisciplinary exposure, by working together.  The students have had the opportunity to interact closely with industry researchers at Qualcomm, Samsung and Facebook.

The work performed in this project seeded a successful UCSB-led bid for a large center (https://comsenter.engr.ucsb.edu/) on mmWave and THz communication and sensing funded by DARPA and the Semiconductor Research Consortium.  The center is led by one of the investigators on GigaNets, and involves 3 of the other investigators.
